CancelJob.name: CancelJob
CancelJob.documentation: This operation cancels a job. Jobs can be cancelled only when they are in the WAITING state.

CreateRevision.name: CreateRevision
CreateRevision.documentation: This operation creates a revision for a data set.

GetAsset.name: GetAsset
GetAsset.documentation: This operation returns information about an asset.

GetDataGrant.name: GetDataGrant
GetDataGrant.documentation: This operation returns information about a data grant.

GetDataSet.name: GetDataSet
GetDataSet.documentation: This operation returns information about a data set.

GetEventAction.name: GetEventAction
GetEventAction.documentation: This operation retrieves information about an event action.

GetJob.name: GetJob
GetJob.documentation: This operation returns information about a job.

GetReceivedDataGrant.name: GetReceivedDataGrant
GetReceivedDataGrant.documentation: This operation returns information about a received data grant.

GetRevision.name: GetRevision
GetRevision.documentation: This operation returns information about a revision.

ListDataGrants.name: ListDataGrants
ListDataGrants.documentation: This operation returns information about all data grants.

ListDataSetRevisions.name: ListDataSetRevisions
ListDataSetRevisions.documentation: This operation lists a data set's revisions sorted by CreatedAt in descending order.

ListDataSets.name: ListDataSets
ListDataSets.documentation: This operation lists your data sets. When listing by origin OWNED, results are sorted by CreatedAt in descending order. When listing by origin ENTITLED, there is no order.

ListJobs.name: ListJobs
ListJobs.documentation: This operation lists your jobs sorted by CreatedAt in descending order.

ListReceivedDataGrants.name: ListReceivedDataGrants
ListReceivedDataGrants.documentation: This operation returns information about all received data grants.

ListRevisionAssets.name: ListRevisionAssets
ListRevisionAssets.documentation: This operation lists a revision's assets sorted alphabetically in descending order.

ListTagsForResource.name: ListTagsForResource
ListTagsForResource.documentation: This operation lists the tags on the resource.

RevokeRevision.name: RevokeRevision
RevokeRevision.documentation: This operation revokes subscribers' access to a revision.

SendApiAsset.name: SendApiAsset
SendApiAsset.documentation: This operation invokes an API Gateway API asset. The request is proxied to the providerâ€™s API Gateway API.

SendDataSetNotification.name: SendDataSetNotification
SendDataSetNotification.documentation: The type of event associated with the data set.

UntagResource.name: UntagResource
UntagResource.documentation: This operation removes one or more tags from a resource.

DataGrantArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the data grant to accept.

Name.documentation: The name of the accepted data grant.

SenderPrincipal.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the data grant sender.

ReceiverPrincipal.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the data grant receiver.

Description.documentation: The description of the accepted data grant.

AcceptanceState.documentation: The acceptance state of the data grant.

AcceptedAt.documentation: The timestamp of when the data grant was accepted.

EndsAt.documentation: The timestamp of when access to the associated data set ends.

GrantDistributionScope.documentation: The distribution scope for the data grant.

DataSetId.documentation: The ID of the data set associated to the data grant.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the accepted data grant.

CreatedAt.documentation: The timestamp of when the data grant was created.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The timestamp of when the data grant was last updated.

ExportRevisionToS3.documentation: Details for the export revision to Amazon S3 action.

ApiDescription.documentation: The API description of the API asset.

ApiEndpoint.documentation: The API endpoint of the API asset.

ApiId.documentation: The unique identifier of the API asset.

ApiKey.documentation: The API key of the API asset.

ApiName.documentation: The API name of the API asset.

ApiSpecificationDownloadUrl.documentation: The download URL of the API specification of the API asset.

ApiSpecificationDownloadUrlExpiresAt.documentation: The date and time that the upload URL expires, in ISO 8601 format.

ProtocolType.documentation: The protocol type of the API asset.

ApiGatewayApiAsset.documentation: The API Gateway API that is the asset.

Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket that is the destination for the asset.

Key.documentation: The name of the object in Amazon S3 for the asset.

S3SnapshotAsset.documentation: The Amazon S3 object that is the asset.

RedshiftDataShareAsset.documentation: The Amazon Redshift datashare that is the asset.

ApiGatewayApiAsset.documentation: Information about the API Gateway API asset.

S3DataAccessAsset.documentation: The Amazon S3 data access that is the asset.

LakeFormationDataPermissionAsset.documentation: The AWS Lake Formation data permission that is the asset.

AssetType.documentation: The type of asset that is added to a data set.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the asset was created, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with this asset.

Name.documentation: The name of the asset. When importing from Amazon S3, the Amazon S3 object key is used as the asset name. When exporting to Amazon S3, the asset name is used as default target Amazon S3 object key. When importing from Amazon API Gateway API, the API name is used as the asset name. When importing from Amazon Redshift, the datashare name is used as the asset name. When importing from AWS Lake Formation, the static values of "Database(s) included in LF-tag policy" or "Table(s) included in LF-tag policy" are used as the asset name.

RevisionId.documentation: The unique identifier for the revision associated with this asset.

SourceId.documentation: The asset ID of the owned asset corresponding to the entitled asset being viewed. This parameter is returned when an asset owner is viewing the entitled copy of its owned asset.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the asset was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

AssetEntry.documentation: An asset in AWS Data Exchange is a piece of data (Amazon S3 object) or a means of fulfilling data (Amazon Redshift datashare or Amazon API Gateway API, AWS Lake Formation data permission, or Amazon S3 data access). The asset can be a structured data file, an image file, or some other data file that can be stored as an Amazon S3 object, an Amazon API Gateway API, or an Amazon Redshift datashare, an AWS Lake Formation data permission, or an Amazon S3 data access. When you create an import job for your files, API Gateway APIs, Amazon Redshift datashares, AWS Lake Formation data permission, or Amazon S3 data access, you create an asset in AWS Data Exchange.

Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket that's part of the source of the asset.

Key.documentation: The name of the object in Amazon S3 for the asset.

Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket that is the destination for the event action.

KeyPattern.documentation: A string representing the pattern for generated names of the individual assets in the revision. For more information about key patterns, see Key patterns when exporting revisions.

AutoExportRevisionDestinationEntry.documentation: A revision destination is the Amazon S3 bucket folder destination to where the export will be sent.

Encryption.documentation: Encryption configuration for the auto export job.

RevisionDestination.documentation: A revision destination is the Amazon S3 bucket folder destination to where the export will be sent.

AutoExportRevisionToS3RequestDetails.documentation: Details of the operation to be performed by the job.

Message.documentation: The request couldn't be completed because it conflicted with the current state of the resource.

ResourceId.documentation: The unique identifier for the resource with the conflict.

ResourceType.documentation: The type of the resource with the conflict.

ConflictException.documentation: The request couldn't be completed because it conflicted with the current state of the resource.

GrantDistributionScope.documentation: The distribution scope of the data grant.

ReceiverPrincipal.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the data grant receiver.

SourceDataSetId.documentation: The ID of the data set used to create the data grant.

EndsAt.documentation: The timestamp of when access to the associated data set ends.

Tags.documentation: The tags to add to the data grant. A tag is a key-value pair.

SenderPrincipal.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the data grant sender.

ReceiverPrincipal.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the data grant receiver.

AcceptanceState.documentation: The acceptance state of the data grant.

AcceptedAt.documentation: The timestamp of when the data grant was accepted.

EndsAt.documentation: The timestamp of when access to the associated data set ends.

GrantDistributionScope.documentation: The distribution scope for the data grant.

DataSetId.documentation: The ID of the data set associated to the data grant.

SourceDataSetId.documentation: The ID of the data set used to create the data grant.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the data grant.

CreatedAt.documentation: The timestamp of when the data grant was created.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The timestamp of when the data grant was last updated.

Tags.documentation: The tags associated to the data grant. A tag is a key-value pair.

AssetType.documentation: The type of asset that is added to a data set.

Description.documentation: A description for the data set. This value can be up to 16,348 characters long.

Tags.documentation: A data set tag is an optional label that you can assign to a data set when you create it. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. When you use tagging, you can also use tag-based access control in IAM policies to control access to these data sets and revisions.

AssetType.documentation: The type of asset that is added to a data set.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the data set was created, in ISO 8601 format.

Id.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set.

Origin.documentation: A property that defines the data set as OWNED by the account (for providers) or ENTITLED to the account (for subscribers).

OriginDetails.documentation: If the origin of this data set is ENTITLED, includes the details for the product on AWS Marketplace.

SourceId.documentation: The data set ID of the owned data set corresponding to the entitled data set being viewed. This parameter is returned when a data set owner is viewing the entitled copy of its owned data set.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the data set was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

Tags.documentation: Key-value pairs that you can associate with the event action.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the event action was created, in ISO 8601 format.

Id.documentation: The unique identifier for the event action.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the event action was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

Type.documentation: The type of job to be created.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the job was created, in ISO 8601 format.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the job was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for a data set.

Tags.documentation: A revision tag is an optional label that you can assign to a revision when you create it. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. When you use tagging, you can also use tag-based access control in IAM policies to control access to these data sets and revisions.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the revision was created, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with the data set revision.

Finalized.documentation: To publish a revision to a data set in a product, the revision must first be finalized. Finalizing a revision tells AWS Data Exchange that your changes to the assets in the revision are complete. After it's in this read-only state, you can publish the revision to your products. Finalized revisions can be published through the AWS Data Exchange console or the AWS Marketplace Catalog API, using the StartChangeSet AWS Marketplace Catalog API action. When using the API, revisions are uniquely identified by their ARN.

SourceId.documentation: The revision ID of the owned revision corresponding to the entitled revision being viewed. This parameter is returned when a revision owner is viewing the entitled copy of its owned revision.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the revision was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

RevocationComment.documentation: A required comment to inform subscribers of the reason their access to the revision was revoked.

Revoked.documentation: A status indicating that subscribers' access to the revision was revoked.

RevokedAt.documentation: The date and time that the revision was revoked, in ISO 8601 format.

AssetSource.documentation: Details about the S3 data access source asset.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with the creation of this Amazon S3 data access.

RevisionId.documentation: The unique identifier for a revision.

AssetSource.documentation: Details about the asset source from an Amazon S3 bucket.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for this data set.

RevisionId.documentation: The unique identifier for the revision.

DataSetEntry.documentation: A data set is an AWS resource with one or more revisions.

A list of LF-tag conditions that apply to database resources.

KmsKeyArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the AWS KMS key you want to use to encrypt the Amazon S3 objects. This parameter is required if you choose aws:kms as an encryption type.

Type.documentation: The type of server side encryption used for encrypting the objects in Amazon S3.

ExportServerSideEncryption.documentation: Encryption configuration of the export job. Includes the encryption type in addition to the AWS KMS key. The KMS key is only necessary if you chose the KMS encryption type.

When exporting to Amazon S3, the asset name is used as default target Amazon S3 object key. When importing from Amazon API Gateway API, the API name is used as the asset name. When importing from Amazon Redshift, the datashare name is used as the asset name. When importing from AWS Lake Formation, the static values of "Database(s) included in the LF-tag policy" or "Table(s) included in the LF-tag policy" are used as the asset name.

Finalized.documentation: To publish a revision to a data set in a product, the revision must first be finalized. Finalizing a revision tells AWS Data Exchange that your changes to the assets in the revision are complete. After it's in this read-only state, you can publish the revision to your products. Finalized revisions can be published through the AWS Data Exchange console or the AWS Marketplace Catalog API, using the StartChangeSet AWS Marketplace Catalog API action. When using the API, revisions are uniquely identified by their ARN.

Message.documentation: The message identifying the service exception that occurred.

Details.documentation: Details of the operation to be performed by the job, such as export destination details or import source details.

JobEntry.documentation: AWS Data Exchange Jobs are asynchronous import or export operations used to create or copy assets. A data set owner can both import and export as they see fit. Someone with an entitlement to a data set can only export. Jobs are deleted 90 days after they are created.

LimitName.documentation: The name of the limit that was reached.

Message.documentation: The message related to the job error.

ResourceId.documentation: The unique identifier for the resource related to the error.

ResourceType.documentation: The type of resource related to the error.

JobError.documentation: An error that occurred with the job request.

enum: Amazon Redshift datashare assets per revision
AWS Lake Formation data permission assets per revision
Amazon S3 data access assets per revision

KmsKeyArn.documentation: The AWS KMS CMK (Key Management System Customer Managed Key) used to encrypt S3 objects in the shared S3 Bucket. AWS Data exchange will create a KMS grant for each subscriber to allow them to access and decrypt their entitled data that is encrypted using this KMS key specified.

KmsKeyToGrant.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the AWS KMS key used to encrypt the shared S3 objects.

Database.documentation: Details about the database resource included in the AWS Lake Formation data permission.

Table.documentation: Details about the table resource included in the AWS Lake Formation data permission.

LFResourceDetails.documentation: Details about the AWS Lake Formation resource (Table or Database) included in the AWS Lake Formation data permission.

LFTag.documentation: A structure that allows an LF-admin to grant permissions on certain conditions.

CatalogId.documentation: The identifier for the AWS Glue Data Catalog.

ResourceType.documentation: The resource type for which the LF-tag policy applies.

ResourceDetails.documentation: Details for the Lake Formation Resources included in the LF-tag policy.

LakeFormationDataPermissionDetails.documentation: Details about the AWS Lake Formation data permission.

Permissions.documentation: The permissions granted to the subscribers on the resource.

RoleArn.documentation: The IAM role's ARN that allows AWS Data Exchange to assume the role and grant and revoke permissions to AWS Lake Formation data permissions.

LakeFormationDataPermissionAsset.documentation: The AWS Lake Formation data permission asset.

LakeFormationDataPermissionDetails.documentation: Details about the AWS Lake Formation data permission.

Database.documentation: The underlying Glue database that the notification is referring to.

Table.documentation: The underlying Glue table that the notification is referring to.

LakeFormationTagPolicyDetails.documentation: Extra details specific to the affected scope in this LF data set.

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of results to be included in the next page.

ResourceArn.documentation: An Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies an AWS resource.

Tags.documentation: A label that consists of a customer-defined key and an optional value.

DataUpdate.documentation: Extra details specific to a data update type notification.

Deprecation.documentation: Extra details specific to a deprecation type notification.

SchemaChange.documentation: Extra details specific to a schema change type notification.

ProductId.documentation: The product ID of the origin of the data set.

OriginDetails.documentation: Details about the origin of the data set.

SenderPrincipal.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the data grant sender.

ReceiverPrincipal.documentation: The Amazon Web Services account ID of the data grant receiver.

AcceptanceState.documentation: The acceptance state of the data grant.

AcceptedAt.documentation: The timestamp of when the data grant was accepted.

EndsAt.documentation: The timestamp of when access to the associated data set ends.

DataSetId.documentation: The ID of the data set associated to the data grant.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the data grant.

CreatedAt.documentation: The timestamp of when the data grant was created.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The timestamp of when the data grant was last updated.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the datashare asset.

DataShareArn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the datashare asset.

RedshiftDataShareAssetSourceEntry.documentation: The source of the Amazon Redshift datashare asset.

Arn.documentation: The ARN of the underlying Redshift data share that is being affected by this notification.

Database.documentation: The database name in the Redshift data share that is being affected by this notification.

Function.documentation: A function name in the Redshift database that is being affected by this notification.

Table.documentation: A table name in the Redshift database that is being affected by this notification.

Schema.documentation: A schema name in the Redshift database that is being affected by this notification.

View.documentation: A view name in the Redshift database that is being affected by this notification.

RedshiftDataShareDetails.documentation: Extra details specific to the affected scope in this Redshift data set.

ExportAssetToSignedUrl.documentation: Details about the export to signed URL request.

ExportAssetsToS3.documentation: Details about the export to Amazon S3 request.

ExportRevisionsToS3.documentation: Details about the export to Amazon S3 request.

ImportAssetFromSignedUrl.documentation: Details about the import from Amazon S3 request.

ImportAssetsFromS3.documentation: Details about the import asset from API Gateway API request.

ImportAssetsFromRedshiftDataShares.documentation: Details from an import from Amazon Redshift datashare request.

ImportAssetFromApiGatewayApi.documentation: Details about the import from signed URL request.

CreateS3DataAccessFromS3Bucket.documentation: Details of the request to create S3 data access from the Amazon S3 bucket.

ResourceId.documentation: The unique identifier for the resource that couldn't be found.

ResourceType.documentation: The type of resource that couldn't be found.

ExportAssetToSignedUrl.documentation: Details for the export to signed URL response.

ExportAssetsToS3.documentation: Details for the export to Amazon S3 response.

ExportRevisionsToS3.documentation: Details for the export revisions to Amazon S3 response.

ImportAssetFromSignedUrl.documentation: Details for the import from signed URL response.

ImportAssetsFromS3.documentation: Details for the import from Amazon S3 response.

ImportAssetsFromRedshiftDataShares.documentation: Details from an import from Amazon Redshift datashare response.

Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket that is the destination for the assets in the revision.

KeyPattern.documentation: A string representing the pattern for generated names of the individual assets in the revision. For more information about key patterns, see Key patterns when exporting revisions.

RevisionId.documentation: The unique identifier for the revision.

RevisionDestinationEntry.documentation: The destination where the assets in the revision will be exported.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the revision was created, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with the data set revision.

Finalized.documentation: To publish a revision to a data set in a product, the revision must first be finalized. Finalizing a revision tells AWS Data Exchange that your changes to the assets in the revision are complete. After it's in this read-only state, you can publish the revision to your products. Finalized revisions can be published through the AWS Data Exchange console or the AWS Marketplace Catalog API, using the StartChangeSet AWS Marketplace Catalog API action. When using the API, revisions are uniquely identified by their ARN.

SourceId.documentation: The revision ID of the owned revision corresponding to the entitled revision being viewed. This parameter is returned when a revision owner is viewing the entitled copy of its owned revision.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the revision was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

RevocationComment.documentation: A required comment to inform subscribers of the reason their access to the revision was revoked.

Revoked.documentation: A status indicating that subscribers' access to the revision was revoked.

RevokedAt.documentation: The date and time that the revision was revoked, in ISO 8601 format.

RevisionEntry.documentation: A revision is a container for one or more assets.

DataSetId.documentation: The data set ID of the published revision.

Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket hosting data to be shared in the S3 data access.

KeyPrefixes.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket used for hosting shared data in the Amazon S3 data access.

Keys.documentation: S3 keys made available using this asset.

S3AccessPointAlias.documentation: The automatically-generated bucket-style alias for your Amazon S3 Access Point. Customers can access their entitled data using the S3 Access Point alias.

S3AccessPointArn.documentation: The ARN for your Amazon S3 Access Point. Customers can also access their entitled data using the S3 Access Point ARN.

KmsKeysToGrant.documentation: List of AWS KMS CMKs (Key Management System Customer Managed Keys) and ARNs used to encrypt S3 objects being shared in this S3 Data Access asset. Providers must include all AWS KMS keys used to encrypt these shared S3 objects.

S3DataAccessAsset.documentation: The Amazon S3 data access that is the asset.

Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket used for hosting shared data in the Amazon S3 data access.

KeyPrefixes.documentation: Organizes Amazon S3 asset key prefixes stored in an Amazon S3 bucket.

Keys.documentation: The keys used to create the Amazon S3 data access.

KmsKeysToGrant.documentation: List of AWS KMS CMKs (Key Management System Customer Managed Keys) and ARNs used to encrypt S3 objects being shared in this S3 Data Access asset.

S3DataAccessAssetSourceEntry.documentation: Source details for an Amazon S3 data access asset.

KeyPrefixes.documentation: A list of the key prefixes affected by this notification. This can have up to 50 entries.

Keys.documentation: A list of the keys affected by this notification. This can have up to 50 entries.

S3DataAccessDetails.documentation: Extra details specific to the affected scope in this S3 Data Access data set.

Size.documentation: The size of the Amazon S3 object that is the object.

S3SnapshotAsset.documentation: The Amazon S3 object that is the asset.

Name.documentation: Name of the changing field. This value can be up to 255 characters long.

Type.documentation: Is the field being added, removed, or modified?

Description.documentation: Description of what's changing about this field. This value can be up to 512 characters long.

SchemaChangeDetails.documentation: Object encompassing information about a schema change to a single, particular field, a notification can have up to 100 of these.

Changes.documentation: List of schema changes happening in the scope of this notification. This can have up to 100 entries.

SchemaChangeAt.documentation: A date in the future when the schema change is taking effect.

SchemaChangeRequestDetails.documentation: Extra details specific to this schema change type notification.

LakeFormationTagPolicies.documentation: Underlying LF resources that will be affected by this notification.

RedshiftDataShares.documentation: Underlying Redshift resources that will be affected by this notification.

S3DataAccesses.documentation: Underlying S3 resources that will be affected by this notification.

ScopeDetails.documentation: Details about the scope of the notifications such as the affected resources.

QueryStringParameters.documentation: Attach query string parameters to the end of the URI (for example, /v1/examplePath?exampleParam=exampleValue).

AssetId.documentation: Asset ID value for the API request.

DataSetId.documentation: Data set ID value for the API request.

RequestHeaders.documentation: Any header value prefixed with x-amzn-dataexchange-header- will have that stripped before sending the Asset API request. Use this when you want to override a header that AWS Data Exchange uses. Alternatively, you can use the header without a prefix to the HTTP request.

Method.documentation: HTTP method value for the API request. Alternatively, you can use the appropriate verb in your request.

Path.documentation: URI path value for the API request. Alternatively, you can set the URI path directly by invoking /v1/{pathValue}.

RevisionId.documentation: Revision ID value for the API request.

Body.documentation: The response body from the underlying API tracked by the API asset.

ResponseHeaders.documentation: The response headers from the underlying API tracked by the API asset.

Scope.documentation: Affected scope of this notification such as the underlying resources affected by the notification event.

ClientToken.documentation: Idempotency key for the notification, this key allows us to deduplicate notifications that are sent in quick succession erroneously.

Comment.documentation: Free-form text field for providers to add information about their notifications.

DataSetId.documentation: Affected data set of the notification.

Details.documentation: Extra details specific to this notification type.

Type.documentation: The type of the notification. Describing the kind of event the notification is alerting you to.

LimitName.documentation: The name of the limit that was reached.

Message.documentation: The request has exceeded the quotas imposed by the service.

ServiceLimitExceededException.documentation: The request has exceeded the quotas imposed by the service.

Expression.documentation: A list of LF-tag conditions that apply to table resources.

TableLFTagPolicy.documentation: The LF-tag policy for a table resource.

Expression.documentation: A list of LF-tag conditions that apply to table resources.

Permissions.documentation: The permissions granted to subscribers on table resources.

TableLFTagPolicyAndPermissions.documentation: The LF-tag policy and permissions that apply to table resources.

ResourceArn.documentation: An Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies an AWS resource.

Tags.documentation: A label that consists of a customer-defined key and an optional value.

Message.documentation: The limit on the number of requests per second was exceeded.

ThrottlingException.documentation: The limit on the number of requests per second was exceeded.

ResourceArn.documentation: An Amazon Resource Name (ARN) that uniquely identifies an AWS resource.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for a data set.

Name.documentation: The name of the asset. When importing from Amazon S3, the Amazon S3 object key is used as the asset name. When exporting to Amazon S3, the asset name is used as default target Amazon S3 object key. When importing from Amazon API Gateway API, the API name is used as the asset name. When importing from Amazon Redshift, the datashare name is used as the asset name. When importing from AWS Lake Formation, the static values of "Database(s) included in the LF-tag policy" or "Table(s) included in LF-tag policy" are used as the name.

RevisionId.documentation: The unique identifier for a revision.

AssetType.documentation: The type of asset that is added to a data set.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the asset was created, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with this asset.

Name.documentation: The name of the asset. When importing from Amazon S3, the Amazon S3 object key is used as the asset name. When exporting to Amazon S3, the asset name is used as default target Amazon S3 object key. When importing from Amazon API Gateway API, the API name is used as the asset name. When importing from Amazon Redshift, the datashare name is used as the asset name. When importing from AWS Lake Formation, the static values of "Database(s) included in the LF-tag policy"- or "Table(s) included in LF-tag policy" are used as the asset name.

RevisionId.documentation: The unique identifier for the revision associated with this asset.

SourceId.documentation: The asset ID of the owned asset corresponding to the entitled asset being viewed. This parameter is returned when an asset owner is viewing the entitled copy of its owned asset.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the asset was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for a data set.

AssetType.documentation: The type of asset that is added to a data set.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the data set was created, in ISO 8601 format.

Id.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set.

Origin.documentation: A property that defines the data set as OWNED by the account (for providers) or ENTITLED to the account (for subscribers).

OriginDetails.documentation: If the origin of this data set is ENTITLED, includes the details for the product on AWS Marketplace.

SourceId.documentation: The data set ID of the owned data set corresponding to the entitled data set being viewed. This parameter is returned when a data set owner is viewing the entitled copy of its owned data set.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the data set was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

EventActionId.documentation: The unique identifier for the event action.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the event action was created, in ISO 8601 format.

Id.documentation: The unique identifier for the event action.

UpdatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the event action was last updated, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for a data set.

CreatedAt.documentation: The date and time that the revision was created, in ISO 8601 format.

DataSetId.documentation: The unique identifier for the data set associated with the data set revision.

Finalizing a revision tells AWS Data Exchange that changes to the assets in the revision are complete. After it's in this read-only state, you can publish the revision to your products. Finalized revisions can be published through the AWS Data Exchange console or the AWS Marketplace Catalog API, using the StartChangeSet AWS Marketplace Catalog API action. When using the API, revisions are uniquely identified by their ARN.

Message.documentation: The message that informs you about what was invalid about the request.

ExceptionCause.documentation: The unique identifier for the resource that couldn't be found.

documentation:
AWS Data Exchange is a service that makes it easy for AWS customers to exchange data in the cloud. You can use the AWS Data Exchange APIs to create, update, manage, and access file-based data set in the AWS Cloud.

As a subscriber, you can view and access the data sets that you have an entitlement to through a subscription. You can use the APIs to download or copy your entitled data sets to Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) for use across a variety of AWS analytics and machine learning services.

As a provider, you can create and manage your data sets that you would like to publish to a product. Being able to package and provide your data sets into products requires a few steps to determine eligibility. For more information, visit the AWS Data Exchange User Guide.

A data set is a collection of data that can be changed or updated over time. Data sets can be updated using revisions, which represent a new version or incremental change to a data set. A revision contains one or more assets. An asset in AWS Data Exchange is a piece of data that can be stored as an Amazon S3 object, Redshift datashare, API Gateway API, AWS Lake Formation data permission, or Amazon S3 data access. The asset can be a structured data file, an image file, or some other data file. Jobs are asynchronous import or export operations used to create or copy assets.
